This #HispanicHeritageMonth, the #WomenVetsTaskForce honors Tech4 Carmen Contreras-Bozak for her notable contributions and distinguished service to our country. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBnweaIVgAQWH8_.jpg

Following her military service, Contreras-Bozak was an active advocate for our nation‚Äôs #womenvets. In 1989, she established the Fort Lauderdale Chapter of WAC Vets and served as the organization‚Äôs first president. She also founded a chapter of the Society of Military Widows. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBnwonVVkAMD3lP.jpg

She was assigned to the Army Signal Corps, where she oversaw the sending and receiving of coded messages between General Dwight Eisenhower in Algiers and the battlefield in Tunisia. Contreras-Bozak proudly served our country for four years, including 18 months overseas. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBnwRQ6VcAYdTx7.jpg

At that time, the Army was in need of bilingual women to work in cryptology, communications, and interpretation. Because of her ability to speak five languages (Spanish, English Portuguese, Italian, and French), she was appointed to the 149th Company and served as an interpreter. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBnwGQwVUAQoGG_.jpg

Six months after the attack on Pearl Harbor, Contreras-Bozak joined the Women‚Äôs Army Auxiliary Corps (WAAC). The unit was later named the Women's Army Corps (WAC). http://pbs.twimg.com/media/FBnwBbbUUAMFv9Z.jpg
